title: Basic Airway Assessment
pcr_text: 35-year-old male responsive but with noisy breathing. Should you assess airway first or take vital signs?
correct_error: Airway assessment first in primary survey per 2022 National EMS Education Standards.

options.text: Assess airway patency and breathing adequacy first
Take blood pressure and pulse first
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Airway assessment is first priority in primary survey.

options.text: Ask patient how they feel

title: Basic Breathing Assessment
pcr_text: 50-year-old female with shortness of breath. Respiratory rate 28, oxygen saturation 94%. What is your immediate action?
correct_error: Breathing assessment includes rate, depth, and oxygen saturation per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Assess respiratory rate, depth, and provide oxygen if indicated
Take blood pressure immediately
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Breathing assessment precedes circulation in primary survey.

options.text: Ask patient about allergies

title: Basic Circulation Assessment
pcr_text: 42-year-old male with chest pain. Pulse 110, skin pale and cool. What should you assess next?
correct_error: Circulation assessment includes pulse, skin condition, and capillary refill per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Assess pulse quality, skin color/temperature, and capillary refill
Listen to heart sounds
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Basic EMT-B assesses pulse and perfusion, not heart sounds.

options.text: Take temperature

title: Mental Status Assessment
pcr_text: 28-year-old female found confused. AVPU scale shows patient is responsive to pain only. What does this indicate?
correct_error: AVPU assessment: A=Alert, V=Voice, P=Pain, U=Unresponsive per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Patient is responsive to pain - significant alteration in mental status
Patient is alert and oriented
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Responsive to pain only indicates altered mental status.

options.text: Patient is sleeping normally

title: Primary Survey Sequence
pcr_text: 60-year-old male unresponsive after fall. What is the correct order of primary survey?
correct_error: Primary survey: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure
Circulation, Airway, Breathing, Exposure, Disability
options.feedback: INCORRECT ORDER! Airway is always first in primary survey.

options.text: Breathing, Circulation, Airway, Disability, Exposure

title: SAMPLE History
pcr_text: Patient with abdominal pain. What does SAMPLE stand for in patient history?
correct_error: SAMPLE: Signs/Symptoms, Allergies, Medications, Past medical history, Last oral intake, Events per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Signs/Symptoms, Allergies, Medications, Past medical history, Last oral intake, Events leading to call
Symptoms, Age, Medications, Pain level, Events, Location
options.feedback: INCORRECT! SAMPLE is specific history-taking format.

options.text: Signs, Assessment, Medical history, Pain, Events, Location

title: OPQRST Pain Assessment
pcr_text: Patient complaining of chest pain. What does OPQRST assess?
correct_error: OPQRST: Onset, Provocation/Palliation, Quality, Radiation, Severity, Timing per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Onset, Provocation/Palliation, Quality, Radiation, Severity, Timing
Onset, Pain level, Quality, Radiation, Symptoms, Treatment
options.feedback: INCORRECT! OPQRST is specific pain assessment format.

options.text: Origin, Pressure, Quantity, Radiation, Severity, Time

title: Vital Signs - Normal Ranges
pcr_text: Adult patient assessment. What are normal adult vital sign ranges?
correct_error: Normal vitals: HR 60-100, RR 12-20, BP 90-140/60-90, Temp 98.6Â°F per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Heart rate 60-100, Respiratory rate 12-20, Blood pressure 90-140/60-90
Heart rate 80-120, Respiratory rate 16-24, Blood pressure 120-160/80-100
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Standard normal ranges are HR 60-100, RR 12-20, BP 90-140/60-90.

options.text: Heart rate 40-60, Respiratory rate 8-12, Blood pressure 80-100/50-70

title: Glasgow Coma Scale
pcr_text: Patient with head injury, eyes open to pain, makes incomprehensible sounds, localizes pain. What is GCS score?
correct_error: GCS: Eyes 2, Verbal 3, Motor 5 = 10 total per 2022 Standards.

options.text: GCS 10 (Eyes 2 + Verbal 3 + Motor 5)
GCS 15 (fully alert and oriented)
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Patient shows neurological deficits - GCS <15.

options.text: GCS 3 (deep coma)

title: Secondary Assessment
pcr_text: Patient stable after primary survey. What is included in head-to-toe secondary assessment?
correct_error: Secondary assessment: Head, neck, chest, abdomen, pelvis, extremities, back per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Head, neck, chest, abdomen, pelvis, extremities, posterior
Vital signs, patient history, treatment
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Secondary assessment is physical examination from head to toe.

options.text: Mental status, airway, breathing only

title: Scene Safety Assessment
pcr_text: Arrive at MVC scene with downed power lines. What is your first action?
correct_error: Scene safety first: Ensure rescuer safety before patient care per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Assess scene safety and call for utilities if power lines involved
Approach patients immediately to provide care
options.feedback: DANGEROUS! Scene safety assessment is first priority.

options.text: Park ambulance and turn on lights

title: Body Substance Isolation
pcr_text: Patient with active bleeding. What PPE is required for direct patient contact?
correct_error: BSI: Gloves, mask if respiratory, gown if splashing per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Non-sterile examination gloves for all direct contact
Full hazmat suit for all patients
options.feedback: OVERKILL! Standard precautions require gloves for blood contact.

options.text: No PPE needed for basic assessment

title: Mechanism of Injury
pcr_text: Patient ejected from vehicle at highway speed. What does this MOI suggest?
correct_error: High MOI: Ejection suggests severe injury potential per 2022 Standards.

options.text: High energy transfer - suspect serious internal injuries
Minor injury - patient is walking around
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Ejection from vehicle at speed indicates high injury potential.

options.text: No injuries - MOI not significant

title: Nature of Illness
pcr_text: Patient called 911 for 'difficulty breathing'. What should you determine first?
correct_error: NOI assessment: Determine if medical or trauma, acute or chronic per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Whether this is medical or traumatic in nature
Patient's exact blood pressure
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Nature of illness determines assessment approach.

options.text: How long ago symptoms started

title: Patient Priority Determination
pcr_text: Three patients: one with chest pain, one with ankle sprain, one with shortness of breath. Who goes first?
correct_error: Priority: Respiratory distress takes precedence over cardiac and minor trauma per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Patient with shortness of breath - airway/breathing threat
Patient with chest pain - cardiac emergency
options.feedback: INCORRECT PRIORITY! Respiratory distress is more immediate threat.

options.text: Patient with ankle sprain - can wait

title: General Impression
pcr_text: Walk up to patient sitting on curb. What should you form immediately?
correct_error: General impression: Overall appearance and chief complaint per 2022 Standards.

options.text: General impression of patient's overall condition and chief complaint
Detailed medical history
options.feedback: INCORRECT! General impression is initial overall assessment.

options.text: Vital signs immediately

title: Chief Complaint
pcr_text: Patient states 'I don't feel well'. What should you determine next?
correct_error: Chief complaint: Patient's primary reason for calling EMS per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Patient's chief complaint and duration of symptoms
Patient's complete medical history
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Chief complaint is the primary symptom or problem.

options.text: Patient's vital signs

title: Baseline Vital Signs
pcr_text: Patient stable after initial assessment. Why are baseline vital signs important?
correct_error: Baseline vitals: Allow comparison if condition changes per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Establish baseline for comparison if patient's condition changes
Determine exact diagnosis immediately
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Baseline vitals track trends, not diagnose.

options.text: Only needed for critical patients

title: Reassessment
pcr_text: Patient loaded in ambulance with chest pain. How often should you reassess?
correct_error: Reassessment: Every 5 minutes for critical patients, 15 minutes for stable per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Every 5 minutes for unstable patients, 15 minutes for stable
Once at beginning and once at hospital
options.feedback: INADEQUATE! Critical patients require frequent reassessment.

options.text: Only if patient complains

title: Transport Decision
pcr_text: Patient with minor laceration, hemostasis achieved. Should you transport or allow to refuse?
correct_error: Transport decision: Consider condition, distance, resources per 2022 Standards.

options.text: Assess patient's condition and ability to refuse transport
Transport all patients regardless of condition
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Appropriate patients can refuse transport after assessment.

options.text: Never transport for minor injuries
